text:
'People around Greater Manchester want to fly from London' says minister on Heathrow expansion Minister says new runway will tell the world 'Britain is ready for business' Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! The country's aviation chief has said a third runway at Heathrow will be good for Greater Manchester - because many people here ‘want to fly from London’. 
Plans for the new Heathrow runway were published this week by the government following months of debate and controversy. 
But the top minister in charge of air policy claims that the £19bn expansion of Heathrow will have benefits for Manchester . 
In an interview with the M.E.N, Lord Tariq Ahmad, the aviation minister, said the move would make it easier for Manchester passengers to reach a broader range of destinations... by connecting to London. 
He said people living around Manchester want ‘increased options’ - to fly from Manchester or from Heathrow, which ‘offers greater connectivity internationally’. Read More Families living under airport flightpath 'could get greater say' on air traffic changes 
He added: “Notwithstanding the excellent work on the ground at Manchester, half a million people in the north west still use Heathrow as a hub for international connectivity so this is good new for the people of Manchester who see London as a hub for business and leisure travel.” 
Manchester airport bosses are trying to sell the northern hub as the go-to international airport for the 22m people living locally within two hours of Manchester. Manchester Airport 
But Lord Ahmad insisted Heathrow expansion would not clash with this, adding: “Airports compete and they will continue to compete in some areas, and in other areas they will complement each other, it will all be part of the UK’s offering to the world.” 
However, Manchester Airport say they are focussing all efforts on direct services to and from the north - adding that passengers DON’T want to fly via Heathrow, 
A spokesman said: “We know from speaking to passengers their overwhelming preference is to fly non-stop to their end destination whenever possible.” Read More Drunken dad-of-one banned from airline for LIFE after going 'purple with rage' on flight 
He said options for those in their catchment were increasing and they aimed to attract more international routes. 
The Heathrow consultation launch coincides with a report from Transport for the North which says there could be 60m more passengers using airports and ports in the north if the government supports links in the north. 
Chris Grayling, Transport Secretary, said by backing the Heathrow runway they were sending a clear signal that ‘Britain is open for business’. 
He added: “The National Policy Statement is a big step forward for what is one of the UK’s most important, major infrastructure projects. Now we want to hear your views on it. This is an important consultation and I encourage everybody to get involved across the country. 
The draft document will be open to a 16-week consultation. An event on this will take place in Manchester in March before a final proposal is laid before Parliament for debate and a vote in the winter of 2017/18. Like us on Facebook
